questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to measure fetal anemia?

choices.text: Peak systolic velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA)

questions.solution:
• Non-invasive method for detecting fetal anemia:
    • MCA peak systolic velocity (MCA-PSV) is the gold standard for detecting fetal anemia, especially in cases of Rh isoimmunization or parvovirus B19 infection.
  • Principle:
  • In fetal anemia, the blood viscosity decreases, leading to increased blood flow velocity in the MCA due to compensatory mechanisms.
  • Doppler ultrasound measurement:
    • MCA-PSV is measured using Doppler ultrasonography and compared with MoM (multiples of the median) values to determine anemia severity.

Assessment of Fetal Anemia

Method

Utility

Invasiveness

MCA-PSV Doppler (Correct Answer)

Gold standard for non-invasive detection of fetal anemia

Non-invasive

Umbilical artery Doppler

Assesses placental insufficiency (not fetal anemia)

Non-invasive

Cord blood sampling (PUBS - Percutaneous Umbilical Blood Sampling)

Directly measures fetal hemoglobin and hematocrit but has high risk of complications

Invasive

Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)

Used for genetic testing in the first trimester, not fetal anemia

Invasive


 

Umbilical artery Doppler (Option A) is incorrect because it primarily assesses placental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia rather than fetal anaemia.

 

Cord blood sampling (Option B) is incorrect because, although it provides direct measurement of fetal haemoglobin, it is invasive and associated with procedure-related risks.


Chorionic villus sampling (Option C) is incorrect because it is used for early genetic testing, not for evaluating fetal anaemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to show the following finding on USG?

choices.text: Metastasis to the breast from another primary site

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fibroadenoma

Explanation:

  • The ultrasound features—round/ovoid hypoechoic mass, parallel orientation (wider than tall)—are classic findings associated with a fibroadenoma, which is a benign breast lesion.

Breast pathology

USG-findings

USG

Simple cyst

(Option B)

  • Anechoic with posterior acoustic enhancement
  • Round or ovoid with a smooth hyperechoic wall

 

Complicated cyst

 

 
  • Internal echoes
  • Fat-fluid level
  • Oil cyst, galactocoel
  • Internal contents move with change in the position of the breast

Complex cyst

 
  • Hyperechoic thin septations
  • BI-RADS 3:Probably benign, needs follow-up

 

Abscess
  • Ill-defined or well-defined outline
  • Maybe anechoic or low-level internal echoes and posterior enhancement

Fibrocystic disease
  • Prominent fibro glandular tissue in the area of a palpable nodule; however, no discernible mass
  • small cysts in the mammary zone

 

Fibroadenoma
  • Round/ovoid hypoechoic mass
  • May have a hyperechoic rim (pseudo capsule)
  • Parallel orientation(wider than tall)
  • May have calcifications

 

Cystosarcoma phyllodes
  • Inhomogeneous, solid-appearing mass is the (most common)
  • A solid mass containing single or multiple, round or cleft-like cystic spaces and demonstrating posterior acoustic enhancement

Fat necrosis
  • Acute
    • New lesion
    • Hyperechoic due to edema
    • BI-RADS 3
  • Late
    • 1.5 years or more
    • Calcified walls causing a posterior acoustic shadow
    • BI-RADS 3

BI-RADS 4/5/6

(Option C,D)

 
  • Hypoechoic mass with irregular wall (spiculated)
  • Taller than wide orientation

Intraductal papilloma
  • Dilated duct
  • Well defined nodule
  • BI-RADS 4A/4B/4C: suspicious for malignancy, biopsy advised

Duct ectasia
  • Dilated ducts with branching tubular anechoic structures
  • Diametre >2 mm

Implant rupture
  • Step ladder sign: linear horizontal hyperechoic bands representing folds in collapsed shell
  • Suggests intracapsular rupture

Silicone granuloma
  • Snowstorm sign: Hyperechoic and well-circumscribed superficial border with dirty posterior acoustic shadow
  • Suggests extracapsular rupture

questions.text: Banana sign on USG is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spina bifida

Explanation:

  • The Banana sign is a term used in ultrasound (USG) to describe a specific appearance seen in spina bifida, a neural tube defect.
  • It is characterized by the shape of the cerebellum, which appears curved or banana-shaped due to caudal displacement of the cerebellum and tethering of the spinal cord.
  • This sign is typically seen in fetal ultrasound and is a key indicator of spina bifida, particularly in cases of myelomeningocele, a type of open spina bifida.

Neural Tube Defects:

Condition

Description

Spina Bifida (Myelomeningocele)

The cerebellum appears flattened and curled at the base, creating a "banana" shape due to tethering of the spinal cord.

 

A lemon sign indicates a flattened frontal bone often seen in spina bifida.

Omphalocele

Abdominal organs protrude through the umbilical cord, covered by a membrane.

Anencephaly

The brain and skull fail to develop fully, leading to severe neural tube defects.

Absence of the brain, with partial or total lack of the skull.

Encephalocele

Brain tissue protrudes through a skull defect, forming a sac-like structure.

 

Omphalocele (Option A): This is a defect of the abdominal wall and does not show the banana sign.

Anencephaly (Option C): This condition involves the absence of the brain and skull and is not associated with the banana sign.

Encephalocele (Option D): This involves a protrusion of brain tissue through an opening in the skull, and does not show the banana sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a benefit of ultrasound (USG) compared to mammography?

choices.text: USG can be used to detect calcifications, asymmetries, and distortions better than mammography
Can be used for guided biopsy
In young females with dense breasts
Can be used to differentiate solid VS cystic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) USG can be used to detect calcifications, asymmetries, and distortions better than mammography.

Explanation:

  • Mammography is superior to USG in detecting microcalcifications, architectural distortions, and asymmetries, which are key features of early breast malignancies.
  • Ultrasound is not effective in detecting tiny microcalcifications (seen in DCIS) because it relies on sound waves rather than X-rays.
  • Mammography remains the gold standard for breast cancer screening, especially in women >40 years.

Comparison of USG vs. Mammography

Feature

Ultrasound (USG)

Mammography

Microcalcifications detection

Poor

Excellent

Architectural distortion

Poor

Good

Best for dense breasts

Yes (young females)

Limited sensitivity

Solid vs. cystic differentiation

Excellent

Poor

Guided biopsy

Yes

Yes (stereotactic)

Radiation exposure

None

Yes (low dose)

 

Can be used for guided biopsy (Option B): Ultrasound is excellent for guided biopsies, as it provides real-time imaging, allowing accurate needle placement for tissue sampling.

In young females with dense breasts (Option C): Ultrasound is particularly useful in young women with dense breasts because mammography may not clearly differentiate between benign and malignant masses in dense tissue, whereas ultrasound can.

Can be used to differentiate solid vs cystic (Option D): Ultrasound is effective in distinguishing between solid tumors and fluid-filled cysts, which helps avoid unnecessary biopsies in cystic cases.

questions.text: Which investigation is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) CT scan

Explanation

  • CT scans (Option A) use X-rays, which are a form of ionizing radiation. In early pregnancy, radiation exposure, especially during organogenesis (weeks 3-8 post-conception), can lead to teratogenic effects (e.g., congenital anomalies), increased risk of miscarriage, or even fetal growth restriction.

Incorrect Options:

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) (Option B ruled out): MRI uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves, not ionizing radiation.

Ultrasound (Option C ruled out): Ultrasound uses high-frequency sound waves to create images.

Doppler (Option D ruled out): Doppler ultrasound is a specific type of ultrasound that measures blood flow.

questions.text: Fetal anaemia is primarily determined by Doppler assessment of which artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Middle cerebral artery

Explanation:

Fetal anemia is best assessed by Doppler measurement of the peak systolic velocity (PSV) in the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA).

  • In fetal anemia, the blood’s oxygen-carrying capacity is reduced, so the fetus compensates with increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity.
  • This leads to faster blood flow in the MCA, which can be picked up on Doppler.
  • An MCA-PSV > 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age strongly suggests moderate-to-severe anemia.
  • Other vessels like the umbilical artery or ductus venosus are more useful for assessing placental insufficiency or cardiac compromise, not specifically anemia.
  • Uterine artery Doppler is about maternal blood flow to the placenta, not fetal hemoglobin status.

Incorrect Options:

Umbilical artery (Option B): Umbilical artery doppler is primarily assesses placental resistance and fetal well-being in cases of suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) or placental insufficiency.

  • High placental resistance → reduced diastolic flow → high systolic/diastolic (S/D) ratio, abnormal pulsatility index (PI), or even absent/reversed end-diastolic flow (AEDF/REDF)
  • In anemia, the problem is low hemoglobin, not placental resistance. Umbilical artery flow may still appear normal until the fetus is severely compromised.

Ductus venosus (Option C): Ductus venosus doppler is used to Evaluates fetal cardiac function and central venous pressure.

  • The ductus venosus shunts oxygen-rich blood from the umbilical vein directly to the heart. Abnormal waveforms (especially reversal of the “a” wave) suggest right heart dysfunction, myocardial compromise, or severe hypoxia/acidosis.
  • DV changes appear late in fetal compromise, often after hypoxia and cardiac decompensation have already set in. It’s more of a late sign in severe anemia, not a screening or early diagnostic tool.

Uterine artery (Option D): Uterine artery doppler is used to assess maternal blood flow to the placenta and screens for risk of preeclampsia and IUGR.

  • Persistent high resistance with an early diastolic notch in the waveform after mid-pregnancy suggests abnormal trophoblastic invasion → risk of placental insufficiency.
  • This tells us about maternal vascular resistance, not fetal red blood cell status. A fetus can be severely anemic with a perfectly normal uterine artery Doppler.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Unicornuate uterus

  • Based on the given hysterosalpingogram image, the correct diagnosis is option C, "Unicornuate uterus."
  • The image demonstrates a single uterine cavity without evidence of a double uterus, bicornuate uterus, or septate uterus.
  • A unicornuate uterus is a condition in which only one half of the uterus develops properly, while the other half fails to develop or is very small.
  • It results from the incomplete development of one Müllerian duct.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Uterus didelphys- Uterus didelphys, also known as a double uterus, is a condition in which there are two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix. It occurs due to incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts during embryonic development.

Option B: Bicornuate uterus- Bicornuate uterus is a condition characterized by a uterus that has a heart-shaped or two-horned appearance. I

Option D: Septate uterus- Septate uterus is a condition characterized by the presence of a uterine septum, which is a band of tissue dividing the uterine cavity into two separate cavities.

Correct Option C: Hysterosalpingography

  • The given image corresponds to a hysterosalpingogram showing bilateral hydrosalpinx, which indicates tubal blockage and the accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tubes.
  • It is a radiologic procedure used to evaluate the anatomy of the uterus and fallopian tubes.
  • During HSG, a contrast medium is injected into the uterine cavity, and X-ray images are taken to assess the shape, size, and patency of the fallopian tubes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)- Magnetic Resonance Imaging is a diagnostic imaging technique that uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures.

Option B: Positron Emission Tomography (PET)- Positron Emission Tomography is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that uses a radioactive tracer to visualize metabolic and physiological processes in the body. It is not typically used for the evaluation of tubal patency or the diagnosis of hydrosalpinx.

Option D: Laparoscopic chromopertubation- Laparoscopic chromopertubation is a surgical procedure performed under anesthesia to assess tubal patency. It involves the direct visualization of the pelvic organs using a laparoscope and the injection of a dye into the uterus to evaluate the spillage of dye through the fallopian tubes.
